justification: “In the mind game paradigm (Jiang, 2013) … This approach allows for the estimation of group-level dishonest behavior.”
“In the color game paradigm … any choice other than 'Not in the lists' can be classified as a payoff-increasing lie, which allows for direction estimation of individual-level dishonest behavior.”

measured_by: percentage estimate question about other participants' dishonesty
justification: The meta-analysis included “a general measure about beliefs about the rate of dishonesty … (e.g., ‘What percentage of participants do you think… would falsely state…’).”

measured_by: scenario-based intention questions (returns fraud and underbilling)
justification: “In the two non-behavioral experiments … we asked participants whether they intended to behave honestly or dishonestly in marketplace scenarios (merchandise returns fraud and not reporting being underbilled).”
Outcome measures included “a manipulation check asking about specific honesty beliefs (‘Generally speaking, most people tend to tell the truth.’).”
Participants rated “trust beliefs (‘Generally speaking, most people can be trusted.’; Delhey et al., 2011).”
They assessed fairness with the item “‘Most people try to be fair and not take advantage of others if they get a chance.’; OECD, 2017.”
Helpfulness was measured by “‘Most people try to be helpful and not just look out for themselves.’; OECD, 2017.”

measured_by: reciprocity item from Perugini et al., 2003 (0–10 scale)
justification: Reciprocity belief was measured with “‘To help somebody is the best policy to be certain that he or she will help you in the future.’; Perugini et al., 2003.”

measured_by: cynicism item from Leung et al., 2010 (0–10 scale)
justification: Cynicism was assessed using “‘Kind-hearted people usually suffer losses.’; Leung et al., 2010.”
